page.title: 11HISTORY OF NENTHEAD
page.content: Nenthead does not appear on Speed's map of 1610, although there would be homesteads in the area at that time. Lead was mined from 1181, but the industry did not flourish until the end of the seventeenth century. The London Lead Co.<Quaker> began buying lead in 1705 and in 1750 took up leases on all local properties.In 1753 the company designed and built a a new village Nenthead.It had houses built for smelters and officials of the Nenthead Mills .Most of the miners lodged at small farms and cottages around it.The Company improved farms and provided good education for miner's children.In 1914 135 children were attending school.The Brownley Hill Mine was fully operational, minerals being brought from the mine by horse and wagon,transferred to an engine and went to the washing floor.
